seo.title: Best Open Source Google Analytics Alternative 2026 - Free & Private
seo.description: Switch from Google Analytics to OpenPanel — open-source, cookie-free, GDPR-compliant analytics with EU hosting. No consent banners needed. Self-host for free or start from $2.50/mo.

hero.heading: The Open Source Google Analytics Alternative
hero.subheading: OpenPanel is an open-source, privacy-first alternative to Google Analytics that combines web analytics with product analytics in one tool. Cookie-free tracking, EU data hosting, and a 2.3 KB SDK that won't slow down your site.

competitor.name: Google Analytics
competitor.short_description: Free web analytics platform from Google that tracks website traffic, user behavior, and conversions with deep integration into the Google advertising ecosystem.

overview.title: Why teams are switching from Google Analytics to OpenPanel
paragraphs: Google Analytics has been the default analytics tool since 2005. But the forced migration to GA4 fundamentally changed the product — the new event-based model has a steep learning curve, the interface is confusing for most users, and data retention dropped to just 14 months on the free tier. Meanwhile, privacy regulations like GDPR and the ePrivacy Directive mean GA4 requires cookie consent banners that hurt conversion rates and annoy visitors.

OpenPanel is built for the post-GA4 world. It's fully open source under the AGPL-3.0 license, which means you can inspect, modify, and self-host the entire codebase. Unlike Google Analytics, OpenPanel tracks visitors without cookies — no consent banners needed, and full GDPR compliance out of the box. Your data stays on EU servers in Sweden, or you can self-host on your own infrastructure for complete data sovereignty.

Where GA4 splits functionality between free and enterprise tiers ($50,000+/year for GA4 360), OpenPanel gives you everything in one package: real-time dashboards, funnels, retention analysis, cohorts, user profiles, custom events, and revenue tracking. The SDK is just 2.3 KB gzipped — over 13x smaller than Google's gtag.js — which directly improves your Core Web Vitals and page load times.

OpenPanel also goes beyond what GA4 offers for free: built-in A/B testing, unlimited data retention (when self-hosted), no data sampling, and direct SQL access to your analytics data via ClickHouse. If you don't rely heavily on Google Ads attribution, OpenPanel gives you better analytics with better privacy at a fraction of the complexity.

summary_comparison.title: OpenPanel vs Google Analytics: Which is right for you?
summary_comparison.intro: Google Analytics and OpenPanel take fundamentally different approaches. GA4 prioritizes Google Ads integration and marketing attribution. OpenPanel prioritizes privacy, simplicity, and data ownership.
summary_comparison.one_liner: OpenPanel is open-source and privacy-first; Google Analytics is free but sends your data to Google and requires cookies.
best_for_openpanel: Privacy-conscious teams who want analytics without cookies or consent banners
EU businesses that need GDPR-compliant analytics with European data hosting
Developers who want to self-host and own their analytics data completely
Teams frustrated with GA4's complexity who want simpler, actionable insights
Sites that care about performance — 2.3 KB SDK vs Google's 30+ KB
Teams who need both web analytics and product analytics in one tool
best_for_competitor: Teams heavily invested in Google Ads who need native conversion tracking and attribution
Large enterprises with dedicated analytics teams running complex multi-touch attribution models
Organizations using the full Google Marketing Platform (Search Console, Ads, Tag Manager)
Teams with zero analytics budget who accept Google's privacy tradeoffs for a free product

highlights.title: Key differences at a glance
highlights.intro: Here's how OpenPanel and Google Analytics compare on the factors that matter most when choosing an analytics platform.

items.label: Open source
items.openpanel: Yes — AGPL-3.0 license, full source code on GitHub

items.label: Price
items.openpanel: From $2.50/month cloud, or free self-hosted with unlimited events
items.competitor: Free tier with limits, GA4 360 starts at $50,000/year

items.label: Cookies
items.openpanel: Cookie-free by default — no consent banner needed
items.competitor: Requires first-party cookies and a consent banner under GDPR

items.label: SDK size
items.openpanel: 2.3 KB gzipped — minimal impact on page speed
items.competitor: 30+ KB gzipped — impacts Core Web Vitals

items.label: Data retention
items.competitor: 2–14 months free tier, up to 50 months on GA4 360

items.label: Data sampling
items.competitor: Yes — free tier samples data at high traffic volumes

items.label: Self-hosting
items.openpanel: Yes — single Docker container, simple setup

feature_comparison.title: Feature-by-feature comparison
feature_comparison.intro: OpenPanel combines web analytics with product analytics. Google Analytics focuses on marketing attribution and traffic analysis within the Google ecosystem.

features.name: Real-time dashboard
features.notes: OpenPanel shows live events; GA4 real-time is limited to last 30 minutes

features.name: Outgoing link tracking
features.notes: OpenPanel tracks automatically with trackOutgoingLinks option

features.name: Custom event tracking
features.notes: OpenPanel uses a simpler track() API vs GA4's gtag event model

features.name: Funnel analysis
features.notes: GA4 funnels require Explorations; OpenPanel has built-in funnel builder

features.name: User profiles & identification
features.notes: OpenPanel has rich user profiles with session history; GA4 uses User Properties

features.name: A/B testing
features.notes: Google Optimize was shut down September 2023 — no built-in replacement

features.name: Custom dashboards
features.notes: GA4 uses complex Explorations; OpenPanel has drag-and-drop dashboard builder

features.name: Attribution modeling
features.notes: GA4 has data-driven attribution — its strongest advantage for advertisers

features.name: Alerts & notifications
features.notes: OpenPanel supports webhooks, Slack, Discord, and email alerts

features.name: SQL access to raw data
features.notes: OpenPanel gives direct ClickHouse SQL access; GA4 requires BigQuery export ($50k+ tier)

features.name: Cookie-free tracking
features.notes: GA4 requires first-party cookies for session and user tracking

features.name: No consent banner needed
features.notes: GA4 requires consent under GDPR and ePrivacy Directive

features.name: EU data residency
features.notes: OpenPanel hosted in Sweden; GA4 processes data on US servers

features.name: IP anonymization
features.notes: Both anonymize IPs; OpenPanel uses daily rotating salts for extra privacy

features.name: Self-hosting option
features.notes: Complete data sovereignty when self-hosted on your infrastructure

features.name: Open source code
features.notes: OpenPanel is AGPL-3.0; you can audit every line of code

features.name: Data export
features.notes: GA4 requires 360 ($50k+) for full BigQuery export; OpenPanel exports freely

features.name: Google Ads integration
features.notes: GA4's strongest feature — native Google Ads conversion tracking

features.name: Google Search Console
features.notes: Native GA4 integration for search data

features.name: Webhooks
features.notes: Send real-time event data to any endpoint

features.name: WordPress plugin
features.notes: OpenPanel has an official WordPress plugin for easy setup

pricing.title: Pricing comparison
pricing.intro: Google Analytics is 'free' in exchange for your visitors' data. OpenPanel offers transparent pricing with a free self-hosted option.

openpanel.description: Cloud hosting starts at $2.50/month for 5,000 events. 100,000 events costs $20/month. Self-host for free with unlimited events, no restrictions. No limits on users, dashboards, projects, or data retention on any plan.

competitor.description: GA4 free tier has significant limitations: data sampling at high volumes, 14-month maximum data retention, limited Explorations, and no BigQuery export. GA4 360 (enterprise) starts at $50,000/year for higher limits, unsampled data, and support. The 'free' tier is subsidized by Google's advertising business — your visitors' data is the product.
competitor.free_tier: Yes (with major limitations and privacy tradeoffs)

migration.title: How to migrate from Google Analytics to OpenPanel
migration.intro: Switching from Google Analytics to OpenPanel takes about 45 minutes for most websites. OpenPanel uses a similar event-based model to GA4, making the migration straightforward.

steps.title: Add the OpenPanel script alongside GA4
steps.description: Install the lightweight 2.3 KB OpenPanel script on your site. Run it in parallel with GA4 so you can compare data. It's a single script tag or npm package.

steps.title: Map your GA4 events to OpenPanel
steps.description: OpenPanel's track() API closely mirrors GA4's event structure. Most events translate directly: gtag('event', 'purchase', {...}) becomes op.track('purchase', {...}).

steps.title: Set up user identification
steps.description: Replace GA4's set user_properties with OpenPanel's identify() method for richer user profiles with session history and properties.

steps.title: Configure dashboards and funnels
steps.description: Set up your reports in OpenPanel's visual dashboard builder. It's simpler than GA4's Explorations — most teams get set up in minutes.

steps.title: Verify data and remove GA4
steps.description: After 1-2 weeks of parallel tracking, compare the data. Once verified, remove the GA4 script. You can also remove your cookie consent banner if it was only needed for analytics.

sdk_compatibility.notes: OpenPanel's track() API closely mirrors GA4's gtag event model. Custom events, e-commerce events, and page views all translate with minimal changes.

historical_data.notes: Google Analytics doesn't provide easy data export. Historical data stays accessible in GA4 for your configured retention period. Most teams start fresh with OpenPanel for cleaner, privacy-compliant data going forward.

use_cases.title: When to choose OpenPanel over Google Analytics
use_cases.intro: OpenPanel is the better choice for teams that prioritize privacy, simplicity, and data ownership over the Google advertising ecosystem.

items.title: GDPR-compliant analytics without consent banners
items.description: Cookie-free tracking and EU-only data hosting mean full GDPR and ePrivacy compliance without annoying consent banners that hurt your conversion rates.

items.title: Open source transparency and control
items.description: Every line of OpenPanel's code is on GitHub under AGPL-3.0. Audit the tracking code, verify privacy claims, and contribute improvements. No black-box data processing.

items.title: Self-hosted for complete data sovereignty
items.description: Deploy OpenPanel on your own servers with a single Docker container. Your analytics data never leaves your infrastructure — critical for healthcare, finance, and government.

items.title: Faster websites with a tiny SDK
items.description: At 2.3 KB, OpenPanel's SDK is 13x smaller than Google's gtag.js. Less JavaScript means faster page loads, better Core Web Vitals, and improved SEO rankings.

items.title: Web analytics + product analytics in one tool
items.description: Get Plausible-style web analytics and Mixpanel-style product analytics (funnels, retention, cohorts, user profiles) in a single tool instead of paying for two.

items.title: Teams frustrated with GA4's complexity
items.description: If your team struggles with GA4's confusing interface, complex event model, and limited Explorations — OpenPanel gives you the insights you need without the steep learning curve.

faqs.title: Frequently asked questions
faqs.intro: Common questions about switching from Google Analytics to an open-source alternative.

items.question: Is Google Analytics open source?
items.answer: No. Google Analytics is a proprietary, closed-source product owned by Google. You cannot inspect the tracking code, verify how your data is processed, or self-host it. OpenPanel is fully open source under the AGPL-3.0 license — the complete source code is available on GitHub for anyone to audit, modify, or self-host.

items.question: Is Google Analytics really free?
items.answer: GA4 is free to use, but the cost is your visitors' privacy — data is processed on Google's US servers and used within Google's advertising ecosystem. There are also significant feature limitations: 14-month data retention, data sampling at high volumes, and no BigQuery export. GA4 360 removes these limits but costs $50,000+/year. OpenPanel offers a free self-hosted option with no limitations, or cloud hosting starting at $2.50/month.

items.question: Why are people switching away from Google Analytics?
items.answer: The main reasons teams switch from GA4 are: 1) Privacy concerns — data sent to Google's US servers creates GDPR compliance issues, 2) Cookie consent banners — GA4 requires them, which hurts UX and conversion rates, 3) GA4 complexity — the new interface and event model have a steep learning curve, 4) Data limitations — sampling, short retention, and limited exports on the free tier, 5) Performance — the 30+ KB gtag.js script impacts page load speed.

items.question: Do I need a cookie consent banner with OpenPanel?
items.answer: No. OpenPanel uses cookie-free tracking by default. It doesn't store cookies or collect personal data, so no consent banner is required under GDPR, ePrivacy Directive, or PECR. This improves user experience and can boost conversion rates by 2-5% compared to sites with consent banners.

items.question: Is OpenPanel GDPR compliant?
items.answer: Yes. OpenPanel is based in Sweden (EU), uses cookie-free tracking, hashes IP addresses with daily rotating salts, stores data exclusively on EU servers, and offers self-hosting for complete data sovereignty. We also provide DPA agreements on request.

items.question: Can I self-host OpenPanel?
items.answer: Yes. OpenPanel can be self-hosted using a single Docker container with our setup script. The entire process takes about 15 minutes. When self-hosted, you get unlimited events, unlimited data retention, and complete control over your data — no usage fees. The source code is available under the AGPL-3.0 license.

items.question: Can I import my Google Analytics data into OpenPanel?
items.answer: Google Analytics doesn't provide an easy data export mechanism, so direct migration of historical data isn't possible. Most teams run OpenPanel alongside GA4 for 1-2 weeks to verify data, then switch completely. Your historical GA4 data remains accessible in Google Analytics for your configured retention period.

items.question: How does OpenPanel compare to other GA alternatives like Plausible or Matomo?
items.answer: OpenPanel is unique because it combines web analytics (like Plausible) with product analytics (like Mixpanel) in one open-source tool. Plausible is simpler but lacks funnels, cohorts, and user profiles. Matomo is feature-rich but requires cookies and has a heavier setup. OpenPanel gives you the best of both worlds with a tiny 2.3 KB SDK.

items.question: Does OpenPanel integrate with Google Ads?
items.answer: No. If you rely heavily on Google Ads conversion tracking and multi-touch attribution, GA4 remains the better choice for that specific use case. OpenPanel focuses on privacy-first analytics for teams that don't need deep Google Ads integration.

items.question: How does the SDK size affect my website's performance?
items.answer: OpenPanel's JavaScript SDK is 2.3 KB gzipped, compared to Google Analytics' 30+ KB. That's a 13x difference that directly impacts your Core Web Vitals scores, page load times, and potentially your SEO rankings. For mobile users on slower connections, the difference is even more noticeable.
